![](images/TQ01.png)

`r hide("Hint")`

`r unhide()`

## Algebraic Fractions

![](images/TQ03.png)

`r hide("Hint")`

*Simplfying* algebraic fractions should begin by *factorising*.

In an exam question, expect both the numerator and denominator to share the *same factor*

`r unhide()`

`r hide("Answer")`

$\dfrac{x-5}{x-3}$

`r unhide()`

`r hide("Solution")`

![](images/TA03.png)

`r unhide()`

![](images/TQ04.png)

`r hide("Hint")`

To add or subtract fractions, the *denominators should be the same*.

`r unhide()`

`r hide("Answer")`

$\dfrac{13x+7}{15}$

`r unhide()`

`r hide("Solution")`

![](images/TA04.png)

`r unhide()`

![](images/TQ05.png)

`r hide("Hint")`

The lowest common multiple of $x+3$ and $x-2$ is $(x+3)(x-2)$.

Start by rewriting each fraction with $(x+3)(x-2)$ as the denominator, adjusting the numerators appropriately.

`r unhide()`

`r hide("Answer")`

$\dfrac{7x+11}{(x+3)(x-2)}$

`r unhide()`

`r hide("Solution")`

![](images/TA05.png)

`r unhide()`

![](images/TQ06.png)

`r hide("Hint")`

The lowest common multiple of $3x$ and $x^2$ is $3x^2$.

`r unhide()`

`r hide("Answer")`

$\dfrac{5x-6}{3x^2}$

`r unhide()`

`r hide("Solution")`

![](images/TA06.png)

`r unhide()`
